title: Be The Inventor
challengeText: You're the inventor and your challenge will be to get these logs hauled efficiently! Drag and drop your best guess from the options to the right.

title: The Power Problem
challengeText: Horses were used extensively to move timber from the forest to the nearest river, railroad or sawmill. It was very hard on the horses and expensive. In addition, Horses where limited in how far they could haul a heavy logging sled. What do you think would work better?

options.label: Oxen
options.feedback: Oxen are tougher and stronger than horses however, oxen are very slow so they weren't suitable. Try a different solution.

options.label: Steam Tractor
options.feedback: Excellent solution! Steam worked, was powerful and simpler. A steam powered Lombard Log Hauler could haul much further than a team of horses and it didn't get tired. Let's call our new machine a Log Hauler!

options.label: Electric Trolley
options.feedback: Alvin Lombard actually tried electricity to power a Lombard Log Hauler. It operated very much like a trolley car. However, it was deemed a failure due to the cost. Try a different solution.

title: Traction
challengeText: Timber was usually moved during the winter when the ground was frozen and sleds could easily be hauled over icey and snowy roads. However, designing a machine that could move under those wintery conditions was rather tricky. What solution would provide the right traction?

options.label: Crawler Tracks
options.feedback: Right you are! In 1900 Alvin Lombard developed and patented the first practical crawler track system. Crawler tracks spread the weight of the machine so it can move over soft ground and have plenty of traction on ice and snow.

options.label: Large Wheels
options.feedback: Wheels would sink in snow and soft ground and the steel wheels of the day offered very little traction on ice and snow.

options.label: Giant Screws
options.feedback: Interesting solution! In 1904 Ira Peavey of Bangor, Maine patented a "Snow Locomotive" which used giant screws to move it through the snow and over ice. Unfortunately, it worked but was not a complete success.

title: Steering
challengeText: The Lombard Log hauler weighs 19 tons. How can such a heavy machine be steered?

options.label: Tiller
options.feedback: Tiller steering was used on many early automobiles and would have been very familiar to Alvin Lombard. However, the Lombard log hauler has approximately 8,000 lbs of weight on the skis. A tiller type steering mechanism would not provide enough mechanical advantage

options.label: Steering Wheel
options.feedback: Perfect! A steering wheel used with gears to provide a 1:40 mechanical advantage worked very well

options.label: Horse
options.feedback: The early Lombard log hauler used a horse to steer the skis. The steersman sat on the front of the machine used a set of reins to direct the horse. However, the horse added cost (they need to eat) and complexity.

title: Cost
challengeText: The Lombard steam Log Hauler worked great. However, it was pretty expensive to operate. How can cost be reduced?

options.label: Reduce Crew
options.feedback: A Lombard steam log hauler required a crew of three: Steersman, Engineer and fireman. All were vital to the successful and safe operation of the machine. Reducing the crew would create many problems.

options.label: Make Smaller
options.feedback: Lombard did produce a much smaller 15 ton steam Lombard log hauler. Featuring a vertical boiler, narrower tracks and being generally smaller than the full size Lombard. Though successful, the cost savings was minimal

options.label: Gas Engine
options.feedback: Correct! In 1909 Lombard developed a prototype gasoline powered log hauler.  In 1917 production focused on the Lombard's "Tractor-Truck" which was smaller lighter, faster, required only a driver and was very simple to operate.

title: Breaks
challengeText: A Lombard steam Log Hauler weighed 19 tons and could pull up to 300 tons of logs loaded on sleds. Going down a hill is going to be a challenge!

options.label: Straw
options.feedback: When horse were used to pull logging sleds straw was placed on the hills to create friction to hold the sleds back.  However, it required a person stationed at each hill to remove the old wet, ice coated straw and lay down a new layer all of which cost money

options.label: Mechanical Brakes
options.feedback: Steam powered Lombard log haulers never had brakes. However, with the introduction of the Lombard Lag Bed tractor in 1912 all gasoline powered Lombards had a powerful, foot operated drum brake mounted on the drive shaft

options.label: Snubbing Machine
options.feedback: Snub lines and snubbing machines were often used to hold back heavy logging sleds when used with horses. However, they were dangerous to use and required a crew to operate which was expensive
